results.title: Le Farceur = the Joker
results.creator_credit: Roland Nonin and Philippe De Broca
results.brief_description:
Edouard Berlon is a happy go lucky character who falls in love with the beautiful wife of a rich industrialist. Unfortunately she does not return his affections. The devastated Edouard reacts by playing sad songs on his bassoon while he waits for death. This eccentric behavior charms the woman into changing her mind and running off with him. His restored exuberance is again dampened when he discovers this beautiful woman is stone cold in bed.

Credits: Producer, Roland Nonin ; director, Philippe de Broca ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Philippe de Broca ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Cassel, Anouk Aimee, Pierre Palau, Georges Wilson, Genevieve Cluny.

results.title: Le Destin de Juliette = the Destiny of Juliette
results.brief_description:
Aline Isserman’s film chronicles twenty years of a woman’s life. Juliette, a simple country girl, is in love with Pierre, a sheperd but she is forced into a marriage with a boring railway worker in order to save her family from poverty and homelessness. The husband, Marcel, is transferred from post to post, and becomes an alcoholic, eventually dying, leaving Juliette free to rebuild her life.

Credits: Producer, Eric Lambert ; director, Aline Isserman ; writers, Michel Dufresne, Aline Isserman ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Bernard Lubat.
Cast: Laure Duthilleul, Richard Bohringer, Veronique Silver, Pierre Forget, Hippolyte Girardot.

results.title: Le Desordre et Apres (1960-1966) Part 11
results.brief_description:
Part 11 of 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By the mid-1960s the industry had reconciliated. The French filmgoing public, and most producers, had lost their sympathy for formal experiment and unbridled self-expression. But it would be an exaggeration to argue that French cinema was essentially unchanged, and that most of the films of the late 1960s resembled those of the previous decade. Much had, in fact, been irretrievably altered. The film community was no longer closed to new talent. New directors (for example, Constantin Costa-Gavras, in 1965) and other personnel entered the industry with much greater ease than during the ‘Tradition of Quality’, though most of them worked on unadventurous, if occasionaly stylish, commercial projects.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992 Our collection holds many of the titles referred to in this episode. Apart from a large selection of works by Truffaut, Melville, Chabrol and Godard of this particular decade, we also recommend the following: Rohmer’s ‘Le signe du Lion’ ; Astruc’s ‘La proie pour l’ombre’ and ‘La longue marche’ ; Franju’s ‘La tete contre les murs’ and ‘Judex’ ; Varda’s ‘Le bonheur’ and ‘Cleo de 5 a 7’ ; Michel Drach’s ‘On n’enterre pas le dimanche’ and ‘Amelie ou le temps d’aimer’ ; Resnais’s ‘L’annee derniere a Marienbad’ and ‘La guerre est finie’ ; Colpi’s ‘Une aussi longue absence’ ; Deville’s ‘Ce soir ou jamais’ and ‘Adorable menteuse’ ; Robert Enrico’s ‘Au coeur de la vie’ ; Alain Robbe-Grillet’s ‘L’immortelle’, ‘L’homme qui ment’ and ‘Glissement progressifs du plaisir’ ; Henri Verneuil’s ‘Melodie en sous-sol’.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Cast: Includes interviews with: Louis Malle, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Pierre Kast, Claude Chabrol, Alain Robbe-Grillet, Eric Rohmer.

results.title: Le Dernier Matin D'albert Camus
results.brief_description:
The life and work of Albert Camus, Nobel prize-winning novelist, playwright, journalist and essayist. This short documentary returns to places that have played a important role in Camus’ life; the ruins of Tippasa, his home in Lourmarin as well as the theatre which was to be his refuge from the trappings of celebrity. It is illustrated with a lengthy interview with the author. Also available in the NLA Collection (#2002445, 16mm).

Credits: Director, Harry Fishbach ; writers, Daisy Loriaux, Jean-Claude Brisville ; photography, Jean-Marie Boussaguet ; music, Rene Thomas, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Text by Albert Camus interpreted by Michel Auclair, narration by Jacques Harden.

results.title: Le Crime de la Mule Noire = the Crime at the Black Mule Inn
results.brief_description:
Following his escape from the Bicetre prison, Vidocq arrives in a small village where a crime has just been committed. Vidocq is mistaken for Inspector Flambard and decides to test his police skills by investigating what really happened at the Black Mule Inn.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Bruno Balp, Jacqueline Danno.

results.title: Le Ciel Est Bleu = the Sky Is Blue
results.brief_description:
A former war correspondant is given a new assignement as a sports journalist and sent to Dublin to cover a rugby match. While on assignment he meets a former American girlfiend and rekindles their affair.

Credits: Director, Serge Leroy ; writers, Serge Leroy, Myriam Lempereur ; photography, Jean-Jacques Rochut ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Frederic de Pasquale, Alexandra Stewart, Harry Brogan, Brian McGrath, Larbi Essakali, Liam O’Callaghan, Grace O’Shaughnessy.

results.title: Le Chevalier de Maison Rouge = the Cavalier Maison Rouge
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1793. Maurice Lindey, a young and fervent revolutionary rescues a mysterious woman from the clutches of the citizen’s army. That same night, Maison Rouge makes an attempts to have the Queen and the royal family escape from the Prison du Temple and a handsome reward is offered for his capture. Lindey follows the musterious woman, only to learn that her name is Genvieve Dixmer and that she is married to the owner of a tannery. Maurice is ivited to the house and recived as a firend. He is far too in love to realise that the house is full of conspirators. He even goes as far as introducing Genevieve to the Queen. When she is caught with a message for the Queen, again, Maurice covers for Genevieve and falls under the suspicion of his revolutionary friends.

Credits: Producer, Robert Paiilardon ; director, Claude Barma ; writers, Jacques Armand, Claude Barma ; photography, Jacques Lemare ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Annie Ducaux, Jean Desailly, Francois Chaumette, Julien Berthau, Dominique Paturel, Anne Doat, Michel Leroyer.

results.title: Le Chaud Lapin = the Hot Rabbit
results.brief_description:
William is a relentless womaniser who has to leave his many conquests behind to go and spend the summer vacation in a country house with relatives of one of his friends. Stranded in the isolated rural cottage, he attempts to bed every female member of the clan. Unsuccessful and extremely frustrated, he is determined to have some fun on his vacation and abandons the whole group in pursuit of a trio of hippyish females who flirted with him earlier.

Credits: Director, Pascal Thomas ; writers, Jacques Lourcelles, Pascal Thomas, Hubert Watrinet ; photography, Colin Mounier ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Bernard Menez, Daniel Ceccaldi, Brigitte Gruel.
